abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Women Development
            Initiatives Project for Ethiopia were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: investing in women's
            development is a worthwhile goal. Success or failure depends
            on the identification, design, and relevance of a project.
            Collaboration of the local administrative officials plays an
            important role for the success of women's economic,
            social, and political empowerment. Success depends on mutual
            understanding between the Regional Coordinating Units
            (RCUs), Facilitators, and Intermediaries. Training and
            Information, Education and Communication (IEC) on legal
            awareness and harmful practices are important and effective.
            Tracking of a project's strengths and weaknesses
            requires a simple but comprehensive and participatory
            monitoring system; and attribution of the impacts to a
            project requires a sound impact evaluation methodology. It
            is possible to empower poor, illiterate women socially and
            economically through small-scale and group-based
            micro-business initiatives. A nation-wide pilot is not
            desirable from both financial and administrative
            perspectives, as it requires a complex and costly
            institutional set up.
